comment.author: 38197978@N02
comment._content:
Ah, I'd guess that their sense of litter-buggery, or vandalism was different from our own! 
Wouldn't you?  And that someone among them picked up the paper... which would have degraded in any case...

Cut the auld guys a bit o' slack..

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/38197978@N02] In all areas of our photographic collections, Richard. The Pic of the Day is the most straightforward, in that I'm searching for photos taken on a particular date.

The other photos that are uploaded every day can be serendipitous finds; have subject matter that I hope will be interesting to all of you; photos that I know some of you will know a hell of a lot more about than we do, so that when you comment, we learn more and can add that information to our NLI catalogue. Some photos I happen on because of other projects that are going on here at the National Library. Sometimes it's as simple as the fact that I have seen a photo and love it (or because it makes me laugh), and I hope it'll have the same effect on others....
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38197978@N02
comment._content:
Still: where do you come across these great images?  Your collections are from a compendium of sources many of us can't guess...
Which is to say: great stuff: thanks.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38197978@N02] Have a look here, Richard, for more general info about our photographic collections: www.nli.ie/en/photographs-introduction.aspx and I always include a link to our catalogue. If you click on that, it'll bring you to similar items, or could become a voyage of photographic discovery... :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: The tour guide, who may also have been coxswain to the boat, carries a bugle. Samuel Carter Hall tells us in 1858:  'The bugle is absolutely necessary to illustrate the beauties of Killarney. To enjoy the lakes it is essential to awake their echoes.'  He also noted a cannon in use at Eagles Nest, at a small cost to the visitor, for the same purpose. Each hotel had its own guides and buglers.  "A Week in Killarney (page 126) by Samuel Carter Hall

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/69587809@N05] How lovely! "... to awake their echoes". Thank you.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Advert for Gaze's Tours in The Morning Post July 27 1899

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] So, your advert is from 1899. I found this from 1895 on the University of Oregon Library website. Hence our Circa 1897 date for this photo is looking pretty good, although I'd still like to know when Gaze's Tours was set up so that we could narrow down the earliest possible date...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Henry Gaze & Sons had been a bg competitor to Thomas Cooke but went bankrupt in 1903 according to this blog
However, it is possible to reach much further back in history for one of the biggest travel failures. As far back as 1903 in fact. Then a company that rivalled Thomas Cook in style and size was the subject of the collapse. Henry Gaze & Son had been around since the mid-1850s and built up a huge business with offices on at least three continents. Henry Gaze himself died in 1894 and the business passed through at least two ownerships prior to its eventual demise.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: All the adverts I've seen are for rather more exotic locations, for example the Chicago Worlds fair, a cruise on the Nile, or the Norwegian fjords.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: This is an account by an American woman who did a tour of Europe (including the Lakes of Killarney) organised by Gaze's Tours in 1890, so that isn't really any help in narrowing it down.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Wouldn't it be a hoot if that Cartersville Young Lady turned up in of our Kissing the Blarney Stone photos?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
